thread.title: European sausages could give you hepatitis, says Exeter scientist | Devon Live

author: Paul Byrne
title: European sausages could give you hepatitis, says Exeter scientist | Devon Live
text:
European sausages could give you hepatitis, says Exeter scientist By Neil_Shaw | Posted: May 22, 2017 By Paul Byrne Comments (0) 
European sausages could give you hepatitis thanks to a mutant 'Brexit virus' spreading out of France, Holland, Germany and Denmark - according to an Exeter scientist. 
The new strain of hepatitis E (HEV) is being linked to pig farms in the four European countries, it could land you with anything from nasty flu-like symptoms to something much more serious. 
Public Health England says it has seen a surge in serious complications from the bug, with 1,244 cases last year. 
HEV used to spread from person to person and could be halted by better hygiene, according to The Mirror . But the mutant virus infects livestock too and scientists believe it now affects 10% of sausages. The bug is killed only by longer cooking times. 
Dr Harry Dalton, a gastroenterologist at Exeter University, told a conference on neurological infectious diseases last week that HEV had become a major threat. 
He said: "I call it the Brexit virus. It attacks the liver and nerves, with a peak in May. It is particularly dangerous for people with suppressed immune systems such as those who have had organ transplants and possibly cancer. The virus seems to come from Europe," Dalton said. 
The Food Standards Agency said the virus had spread to most British pig herds with 93% of animals infected and 6% producing enough of the virus to infect humans. 
Dalton said nobody should eat "pink" pork and advised pregnant women and transplant patients not to eat pork at all. 
The virus is found naturally in a wide range of animals but pigs are responsible for most human cases. 
Most transmission comes through consuming raw or undercooked meat, particularly sausages, salamis, cured meats and liver-based products. 
Hepatitis E is also more dangerous for anyone with existing health problems, particularly liver disease, which is also on the rise because of heavy drinking, obesity, diabetes and other members of the hepatitis family.
